introData.title: Direction Signs
introData.text:
To describe a movement in a specific direction, direction signs are used. They come in 9 variations which define the horizontal direction.

The vertical direction is defined by the inner pattern. To indicate a downwards direction, the sign is filled black. To indicate a purely horizontal direction, a dot is placed in the middle. An upwards direction is defined by diagonal lines.

introData.title: Direction Signs
introData.text: To further specify the direction, a relationship pin can be placed in the middle of the sign. These pins shift the direction 30° into the direction of their pinhead.

introData.title: Direction Signs
introData.text:
To specify the relative position of the acting body part after the movement, another relationship pin can be placed left or right of the sign.

An upwards pin signifies that the body part ends up in front of the other sign, while a downwards pin signifies that it ends up behind.

An example would be a side-step, where this is used to note which foot is placed in front of the other.

introData.title: Direction Signs
introData.text: Space measurement signs can be placed below direction signs. This changes the amount of flexion or extension of the body part during the movement. For example a “wide” sign below an upwards movement of the arm would mean that the arm is fully extended.
